card.angular.content: Until recently, my favorite JS frameworks / libraries. I made a few mini projects in it and I like it, that a lot of functionality is natively supplied with TypeScript
card.angular.description: Framework and platform for creating SPA, written in the TypeScript language
card.angular.title: Angular
card.antd.content: I know well and often use as in both business and private projects
card.antd.description: The React.js library contains a set of useful components to help you create a graphical interface
card.antd.title: Ant Design - React
card.bootstrap.content: The last one I use less often, but I know most of the basic components + of course grid
card.bootstrap.description: The CSS library contains a set of useful tools to help you create a graphical interface
card.bootstrap.title: Bootstrap
card.css.content: In css I do not recall the thing that I would not do, everything is a matter of time. When it comes to particulars, I know: positioning, flex, transition, transform, animation and of course more basic functions. I never used grid.
card.css.description: It is used to describe the form of web page presentation
card.css.title: CSS3
card.git.content: At first, I used commands from the terminal, but with time I moved to the Intelli-Interface (especially useful in conflicts). With both approaches, I have never encountered greater difficulties.
card.git.description: Version control system, especially useful for group work
card.git.title: Git
card.html.content: Nothing special just a set of tags, which in the vast majority I know together with their attributes.
card.html.title: HTML5
card.java.content: I know the basic level, when it comes to adding functionalities, my knowledge is based on copy + paste from other code snippets, but I have no problem reading the code associated with the REST API
card.java.description: Class-based object-oriented programming language for general use
card.java.title: Java
card.javaScript.content: I mastered JS in a stupa enabling the creation of advanced functionalities. In addition to JS, I also know such libraries as lodash, moment.js or jQuery, although I would prefer not to use the latter.
card.javaScript.description: The programming language used on websites
card.javaScript.es6.content: I know all the used ES6 functions so much that I do not like using the ES5 syntax anymore
card.javaScript.es6.title: JavaScript ES6
card.javaScript.title: JavaScript
card.jest.content: Useful, pleasant, simple (although not from the beginning)
card.jest.description: JavaScript Testing Framework with an emphasis on simplicity
card.jest.title: Jest
card.liqui.base.description: Database-independent library for tracking, managing and applying database schema changes
card.liqui.base.title: Liquibase
card.react.content: I love to create a lot of small, simple, generic components, which later create larger components, etc. React.js has become my favorite library / framer since the version with hooks.
card.react.description: JavaScript library, which is used to create graphical interfaces of the application.
card.react.native.content: After getting to know this technology, I am not convinced of it, theoretically it is a react, but sometimes doing a simple thing is extremely complicated. In brief, I know the basics, but I do not like using it.
card.react.native.description: Mobile application framework for building graphical interfarts
card.react.native.title: React-Native
card.react.title: React.js
card.react.ts.content: React without typing would be a heavy management, which is why I think TypeScript in React is an indispensable element
card.react.ts.description: The combination of both technologies allows greater clarity of the code and avoids the mass of errors already at the code production stage
card.react.ts.title: React + TypeScript
card.rwd.content: The most interesting thing from sass / css, (except maybe for all kinds of animations). Sometimes it seems to me that I am too much for the creation of a fully responsive view.
card.rwd.description: The technique of page design, so that the layout automatically adjusts to the size of the browser window
card.rwd.title: Responsive Web Design
card.sass.content: In scss I know variables, nesting + syntax, placeholders and maxins. I have not needed any more functionalities so far and I do not think they need them. As for Sass, I do not like the approach without braces and semicolons
card.sass.description: Sass is a preprocessor scripting language that is compiled into CSS
card.sass.title: SASS/SCSS
card.sql.content: I can create basic CRUD scripts in XML and SQL
card.sql.description: Structured text of queries used to create, modify databases and retrieve data from databases
card.sql.title: SQL
card.typeScript.content: My favorite feature JS, I type, I create interfaces, declare the types I can only get and I hate the type 'any', all the way to make the code self-documenting and clear.
card.typeScript.title: TypeScript
card.vue.content: I used Vue.js for one project using CLI and smaller pairs using CDN. I like the mix of Angular and React
card.vue.description: JavaScript framework for building user interfaces
card.vue.title: Vue.js
card.webpack.content: From project to project, each configuration is getting faster and faster, although I still have to search for everything after the documentation.
card.webpack.description: It is a module bundler primarily for JavaScript
card.webpack.title: Webpack
home.sub.title: I'm a front-end developer at Escola Sp. z o.o
home.title: Hi, I'm Przemek
progress.1: My first contact with the frontend
progress.2: First steps in HTML5 and CSS3
progress.3: My first mini projects using HTML5 and CSS3
progress.4: First steps in CSS framework - Bootstrap
progress.5: Course organized by ALX: "Tworzenie stron WWW", where I developed my skills with HTML5, CSS3, Bootstrap, and learned the basics of JavaScript and Responsive Web Design
progress.6: I'm starting to learn online courses such as codeacademy or freeCodeCamp
progress.8: I'm starting to create more advanced mini projects using HTML5, CSS3, RWD, jQuery
progress.9: Kodilla Bootcamp, where I develop my previous skills and get to know SASS / SCSS, Git and more advanced JavaScript. During the course I create about 10 mini projects Photoshop => HTML, all of these projects are fully responsive
progress.10: I'm starting to get a job as a front-end developer
progress.11: I'm starting to experiment with JavaScript frameworks: React.js and Angular.js, but I'm not doing well and I deside to focus on vanilla JavaScript
progress.12: Focusing on JavaScript, it solves dozens of non-hundreds of smaller and larger tasks on codewars website
progress.13: When solving tasks for Codewars, I begin to use ES6 syntax
progress.14: My first mini commercial project, the so-called "landing page"
progress.15: I'm buying my first courses in the Udemy website (with time there will be quite a lot of them)
progress.16: I have a lot of job interviews
progress.17: I have a job interview at Pentacomp Systemy Informatyczne S.A.
progress.18: I get feedback from Pentacomp, that I have successfully passed the recruitment process and after agreeing on the terms of the contract, I agree to establish cooperation as a Front-end developer
progress.20: I join the Java team that recently started to implement the project for Bank BGŻ BNP Paribas under the name ILegal, providing a workflow for bank lawyers. My main task is stylization of the project.
progress.21: I am a co-presenter of the presentation entitled 'Angular vs React vs Vue', my part is a part of Angular and Vue
progress.22: Together with the team, we join another team and jointly implement the LIMS project. This application is to provide workflow for GIOS employees in the matter of testing water samples. It uses such front-end technologies as React.js and TypeScript
progress.23: TypeScript is becoming my favorite JavaScript feature
progress.24: I'm starting to write first functionalities in Java and scripts in Liquibase
progress.25: Together with the team, we are launching the project of the Surface Water Quality Portal. It is supposed to be a widely available application and should contain a CIEP publication on water quality in Poland. The application will use front-end technology such as React.js, TypeScript and React-Native.
progress.26: I get to know React Hooks, in which I see a giant sub-podium. I also propagate knowledge in a team and introduce changes to the PJWP project
progress.27: Correction of WCAG 2.0 errors after an audit by the Fundacja Widzialni for the PJWP project.
progress.28: Obtaining the "Site Without Barriers" certificate from the Visible Foundation. It gives me tremendous satisfaction, because it is 100% my work and makes me realize that on the front-end I am able to do everything.
progress.29: Together with the team, we are starting the implementation of the SPWD MX project - this is a sub module of a larger project for the Warsaw City Guard aimed at administering and collecting information from other modules. There is also a project 100% using React Hooks.
progress.30: I significantly improve my work in TypeScript by creating much more Generally typed components. I am also starting to improve my skills in JEST tests, but the project is not too short to refine my skills
progress.31: While my team focuses on typical back-end projects, I am hired to another team to adapt the SPWD - Portal Mieszkańca project to WCAG requirements
progress.32: Together with the team, we take over a production project for Kozminski University, Kozminski University - Conclusions.
progress.33: Due to the fact that the application ALK - Conclusions is quite a complicated application and in addition it does not provide TypeScrit, I am pushing the idea in the team to change the configuration and rewrite the main components from JavaScript to TypeScript
progress.34: Implementation the client's request the development of ALK applications
progress.35: Implementation of 3 update packages for the BNP Paribas client for the Ilegal application
progress.36: Due to the fact that the Ilegal application is a typical back-end application, and at this time there are no other front-end orders for me, I am starting to write 100% Java code
progress.37: I am significantly improving my Java code reading and writing skills
progress.38: I am creating a "Mock" mobile application for the BPN Paribas client for the purposes of the presentation. It is a web application with a resolution adjusted to 360px width. Within 5 working days, I am able to create views: logins with different types of users, a list of cases for lawyers with filtering, and a screen for creating and editing a case.
progress.39: Implementation the client's request the development of Ilegal applications
progress.40: Implementation the client's request the development of ALK applications - creating additional 5 proposals
progress.41: Implementation the client's request the development of Ilegal applications - integration with an external system
